Search game
Use simple mechanics to push 6 of the opponent's pieces out of the board!
Very simple game, but, will you be able to win everytime?
The most widespread of the Mancalas.
The most widespread multiple-lap Mancala.
The Irish version of the Tafl game family! Invaders must capture the king, defender must make him escape!
Get rid of all of your opponent's pieces on a board that shrinks little by little!
Put two pieces on the board at each turn, and be the first to align six pieces!
Hide all of your pieces before your opponent does, or risk to be discovered!
Pass the ball up to the side of the opponent to win the game!
Drop your pieces and move them around to align two pieces of the same color across the board to win!
Stack your pieces and control as many stacks as you can to win!
An enhanced tic-tac-toe where piece can encapsule other and prevent them to win.
An antiquity-war inspired game. Be the first to pierce your opponent's lines!
A hexagonal game of alignment. Insert your pieces on the board to capture your opponent's pieces!
The oldest strategy game still practiced widely. A territory control game.
A hexagonal alignment game with weird "diagonals"!
You are in charge of a hive full of insects. Use the abilities of your insects to block the opponent's queen in order to win!
The Viking board game! Invaders must capture the king, defender must make him escape!
A modern version of the famous African strategy game!
Your goal is simple: reach the last line. But the piece you move depends on your opponent's last move!
Similar to checkers, capture opponent's pieces, free your own, and immobilize your opponent to win the game!
Regroup your pieces to win. But your possible moves will often change!
Push and crush your opponent's pieces using magnetic forces!
Win points by capturing pieces, but you only control pieces on your side of the board!
The classical 4 in a row game!
Drop a piece, then rotate a quadrant. The first player to align 5 pieces wins!
You can align 5 pieces to win, or you can capture 10 pieces of your opponent to win!
Overlay your pieces and use two game mechanics to conserve your pieces. First player to run out of pieces loses!
Create a winning alignment. The problem: you don't pick the piece that you're placing on the board!
Align 5 of your pieces on a board where pieces slide!
Sandwich your opponent's pieces to dominate the board!
Immobilize one of your opponent's pyramids before your opponent does!
Be the first to push a mountain out of the board!
Put your hexagonal pieces next to another one, and create one of the 3 victorious shapes to win!
Duplicate yourself to conquer the board!
Lapland version of the Tafl game family! Invaders must capture the king, defender must make him escape!
Align your 4 pieces or form a square with them to win!
Align 5 pieces of your color in a row, but beware, the pieces can be put on top of other pieces!
A version of Go on triangular spaces!
Align your pieces to score points, but beware, pieces can flip!

EveryBoard

EveryBoard is a website to play and learn the rules of various abstract strategy games with perfect information. Such games are games that do not include any randomness, agility, or hidden information. These games are played by two players, turn by turn.

Congratulations, you completed the tutorial.
You cannot click, this is a demo.
You cannot move more than of your pieces!
You don't have enough pieces to push that group!
You cannot push this piece because it is blocked by one of yours!
This line contains pieces of your opponent or empty spaces, which is forbidden.
This move is impossible, some landing spaces are occupied.
This space is not aligned with the current line.
Number of pieces to capture in order to win
Maximum pushing group size
Score
At Abalone, the object of the game is to be the first player to push 6 opponent's pieces out of the board. Let us see how!
Moving a piece

At each turn, move one, two, or three pieces either along their line, or on their side. For your moves you can therefore choose between up to 6 directions. The pieces you move must be aligned and consecutive, and the move should land on an empty space (except to push, we will see that later). To make a move, click on one of your pieces, then click on an arrow to choose the move direction.

You're playing Dark, make any move!
Pushing

To push one opponent piece, you must move at least two of your pieces. To push two opponent pieces, you must move three of your pieces. If one of your pieces is in the way, it will be impossible to push. You cannot move more than three pieces.

Only one push towards the right is possible here, find it. (You're playing Dark).

To translate a group of piece, you must select the first piece, then select the last piece, then click on one of the 4 lateral direction the group can move without touching opponent pieces.

Go ahead, translate some pieces.
This is no translation, this is a "pushing move", try a translation.
Congratulations! You know everything you need to start a game!

You will see when creating a game that you can configure two things.

First, the number of capture needed to win, this help create shorter game if wanted.

Last, the maximum size of a moved group. The default is 3 but if you want more chaotic and fun game, you could bump that limit up and play a "powerfull" alternative version of the game!
MCTS
Pieces should only move downward!
That square is already full, you cannot put a piece in it!
You have no pieces in that square, select one that contains at least one of your pieces!
There are no remaining pieces of that color to drop!
There is no possible transfer from that square!
Full Board
Rightmost Focus
Increment

At Apagos, there are 4 squares, each of them has a fixed number of holes for pieces. Each player starts with 10 pieces. Dark pieces belong to the first player, light pieces belong to the second one. The game ends when no one can play. The player owning the most pieces in the rightmost square wins!
Drop

There are two kinds of moves. One is the drop. To do one, you must click on a visible arrow, being of your color or the opponent's. If the chosen square is one of the 3 leftmost ones, it will exchange position with the square on its right.

You're playing Light. Drop a piece on one of those three squares.
Transfer

The other kind of move is the transfer.
  1. Choose one of your pieces on the board by clicking on the square in which it is.
  2. Choose its landing square by clicking on one of the arrow to finish the transfer.
It can only be done with your pieces, from a higher square to a lower one.

You're playing Dark, do a transfer!
This move is a drop, please do a transfer!
Victory

When you put a last piece into a square, the games end. In this configuration you can win.

You're playing Light, do the winning move!
You actively made your opponent win!
Wrong choice, your opponent will win in the next turn no matter which piece is dropped!
Captures > Freedom
Your piece must land on one of the closest six triangles with the same color as the triangle on which the piece is.
You do not have enough tiles to exchange in order to capture this piece. Pick one of your piece and move it.
Your first click must be on the piece that you want to move, or on a piece of your opponent that you want to exchange against two tiles.
You cannot capture from an empty space.
Pieces > Threats > Tiles
Pieces > Tiles > Freedom
Use small board

Coerceo is played on a board like this, composed of hexagonal tiles, each comprising 6 triangles. The triangles are the spaces on which pieces move during the game. The tiles can be removed from the board (you will see how later). The dark pieces belong to the first player and can only move on the dark spaces, while the light pieces belong to the second player and can only move on the light spaces. The object of the game is to capture all of the opponent's pieces.
Move

To move a piece, you need to:
  1. Click on one of your pieces.
  2. Click on one of the triangular space highlighted in yellow.
You can pass through the opponent's pieces.

You're playing first, hence you're playing Dark. Perform any move.
Congratulations! Let's see captures now.
Captures

Every piece has three neighboring triangular spaces (2 on the sides). When all neighboring spaces except one are occupied, and one opponent moves to that last free space, your piece is captured! However, it is possible to place a piece between 3 of the opponent's pieces (or 2 on the side) without being captured.

You're playing Light, make a capture.
Failed, you have not captured any piece.
Gain a tile

When a tile is empty, it can become removable from the board. For it to be removable, at least three of its sides must be free, and these should be neighboring sides. Note that if one empty tile, neighboring a tile that was just removed, also becomes removable, it will be removed too. For example, here, the topmost dark piece will not disconnect its tile when leaving it. But, by leaving the bottom left tile, two tiles will be removed.

You're playing Dark, perform a move that lets you gain two tiles.
Failed, you have not gained the two tiles that you could, try again!
Exchanging a tile

When you have a tile, you can see it on the left of the board. As soon as you have two, you can click on an opponent's piece to capture it immediately instead of moving one of your pieces. This will cost you two tiles. If any tiles are removed during that turn, nobody will get them.

You're playing Light, gain some time and capture the last piece to win directly!
It's nice to move a piece, but you could have had the opponent's piece immediately by clicking on it!
Special capture

When a tile is removed from the board during your turn, some of the opponent's pieces may have lost their last free neighboring space, they will therefore be captured! If this happens to one of your piece during your turn, it will however stay on the board.

A move that demonstrates both of these things can be done on this board by Light. Try it!

Congratulations! See, your piece no longer had any empty neighboring space after you have gained the tile, but it stayed on the board as it was your turn. However, the opponent's piece has disappeared because the tile's capture has removed its last empty neighboring space.
Alignment
Connect Six is played on a 19x19 board, on which stones are put on the intersections. The object of the game is to align 6 of your pieces.
First turn

At the first turn, the first player plays only one piece.

You're playing Dark, place your first piece by clicking on an intersection.
Next turns

On all following turns, the players play two pieces, until a victory or a draw is reached.

You're playing Light, do the winning move.
Your piece should land on a neighboring square.
You cannot drop a piece during the moving phase.
You cannot move a piece before both players have dropped all of their pieces.
A jump must be made over a piece, not over an empty square.
A drop must occur in the central zone of the board.
A jump must land two squares from its original position, and be done in a straight line in any direction.
You are visiting the same location twice in a move, you are not allowed to do so.
Jump

Conspirateurs is played on a 17x17 board. The object of the game is to place all of your pieces in shelters, which are the special squares on the edge of the board. Note the central zone in the middle of the board, where each player will put their pieces initially.
Initial phase

In the initial phase of the game, each player drop their 20 pieces, one per turn consecutively, in the central zone of the board. This phase does not allow any other kind of move.

You're playing Dark, drop one of your piece in the central zone.
Simple move

Once all pieces have been placed, there are two kind of moves that can be performed. The first is a simple move in any direction, orthogonally or diagonally, of a single step.

You're playing Dark. Click on one of your piece and perform such a move.
You have made a jump, not a simple move. Try again!
Jumps

The other type of move is a jump. A piece can jump over a neighboring piece in any direction, as long as it lands directly on the square after that piece, along the same direction.

You're playing Dark. Perform a jump by clicking on one of your piece that can perform a jump, and then on the target square. You may need to click a second time on the target square to confirm your jump, in case your piece is still highlighted (we will see shortly why this is useful).
You have not performed a jump. Try again!
Chaining jumps in a single move

Jumps can be chained when possible. You can decide whether to continue a jump or to stop it at any time. To finish your jump, click a second time on your current location. Otherwise, simply keep clicking on your next location. Once no more destination is possible, your move will end without you needing to click the piece a second time.

You're playing Dark and you can perform a triple jump! Do it.
Congratulations! You now know everything to play the game. Remember: to win, you have to place all of your pieces in shelters before your opponent does.
You have not performed a triple jump. Try again!
You cannot move the piece holding the ball.
You must move by exactly one orthogonal space.
The path of this pass is obstructed.
A pass must be done in a straight line, orthogonally or diagonally.
You can only perform one pass per turn.
You can only perform two translations per turn, not three.
You cannot pass the ball to the opponent. You must pick one of your pieces.
The goal of Diaballik is to bring your ball, represented by the small circle, into the home line of the opponent (i.e, its starting position). The ball is currently being held by your center piece.

During a turn, you are allowed up to three actions, including at most two translations. A translation is an orthogonal step of any piece that does not hold the ball.

Move your leftmost piece by one step. Once you are done, click on the green button that will appear on the bottom right of the board to indicate that you are done with your turn.
Pass

Another action that you are allowed to do at most once per turn is a pass. You can pass the ball by clicking on the piece that holds the ball, then on another one of your piece that can receive it. A pass must be made in a straight line along an unobstructed path.

Here, playing Dark, you can make two moves and a pass to win the game, do it!
Blocking the opponent

There is a special anti-game rule. If a player forms a contiguous line, with one piece in each column, they block the opponent from reaching their home line. If the opponent is in contact with three pieces in this case, they win instantaneously.

Here, playing Light, your opponent is blocking you and you already have two pieces in contact with their line. If you can connect a third piece, you win. Do it!
AllMoves
MCTS (3 only)
MCTS (without dups)
MCTS (3, no dups)
Distance ()
Dummy
You do not have any pieces of this type anymore.
You cannot play here: this space is already full.
You cannot add more pieces to the target stack, as it will contain more than 4 pieces.
To perform a shift, you must move the pieces to a neighboring space.
You must first select either a piece from the side, or a stack of pieces to shift on the board.
Initial board and player pieces

Diam's board is a circular board made of 8 spaces. Each player has 8 pieces: 4 of one color, and 4 of another color. Initially, the board is empty. All the remaining pieces are displayed next to the board: Dark's pieces are on the left, Light's pieces are on the right.

At Diam, the goal is to align two of your pieces, having exactly the same color, on diametrically opposed spaces, on top of at least another piece. Note here that Dark does not win because the dark pieces are not on top of any other piece. You're playing Light. Here, you can win by dropping one of your pieces on the leftmost space. You can do it by clicking on the corresponding piece next to the board, and then on the space in which you want to drop your piece.

You're playing Light, win the game!
Failed, you should drop your piece on the leftmost space, using the piece of the same color of the other piece you already have on the board.
Types of move

You can perform two types of move: either dropping one of your piece like you did in the previous step, or you can shift one of your pieces on the board to a neighboring space. You can pick any of your piece on the board, even if there are pieces on top of it. Only one condition applies: there can never be more than 4 pieces in a space. When you pick a piece with other pieces on top of it, all the other pieces move with yours.

You're playing Dark, try to move one of your piece that is already on the board.
Failed, try to move one of your piece that is already on the board.
Special case

It can happen that, in a single turn, both players reach an alignment. If it is the case, only the player with the highest alignment wins.

Here, playing Dark, you can win by performing such a move, do it!
Failed, try to shift a stack of pieces to the left.
You must select a piece or a stack of your color.
You must select a stack.
This stack cannot be moved because all 6 of its neighbors are occupied. You must select a stack with strictly less than 6 neighbors.
This stack cannot move because it could never land on another piece.
A stack must always be moved by as many spaces as there are pieces in the stack.
The stack must land on an occupied space.
A stack must move in a straight line.
Stacks
Moving

At Dvonn, each hexagonal space contains a stack of pieces. If no number is indicated on a stack, it means that it only contains one piece. The number written on a stack indicates the number of pieces within that stack, hence the number of points its owner gets. The owner of a stack is the one that has a piece at the top of the stack. Only the owner of a stack can move it. A stack cannot be moved if it is surrounded by 6 other stacks. A stack is moved by as many spaces as there are pieces within, in a straight line, and it should land on an occupied space. This line cannot move along the vertex of two neighboring spaces, as would a vertical move. Therefore, there are six possible directions. The player with dark pieces starts.

You're playing Dark, click on a stack and move it by one space.
Disconnection

Pieces with a lightning strike are called "sources". When a stack is not directly nor indirectly connected to a source, it is removed from the board.

You're playing Dark, try to disconnect the stack of 4 pieces from your opponent. There are two ways of doing that, one is better than the other: try to find that one!

You have successfully disconnected the stack of 4 pieces of your opponent, but on the next move your opponent will be able to move on your new stack, and to win the game! There exists a better outcome of this situation, try to find it.

Nice, you have disconnected 4 pieces of your opponent, and your new stack cannot be reached by your opponent! Your opponent therefore lost 5 points: 4 from the disconnected stack, and one from the stack on which you moved. Disconnected stacks will not be visible at the next turn.
Moving on a source

You are allowed to move your stacks on any other stack. This means that you can take control of a source by moving one of your stack on top of it. This way, you know that this stack may never be disconnected, as it contains a source.

You're playing Dark and you can take control of a source, do it!
You have not taken possession of a source, try again.
Congratulations! However, note that your opponent could later take possession of one of your stack that contains a source, so watch out when you take control of sources!
Passing

It can happen that you have no possible move to make. If this is the case, and if your opponent can still move, you must pass your turn.

This is a situation that occurs here for Dark.

When no more move is possible for both players, the game ends and the player with the most points wins.

You're playing Dark, make your last move.
Congratulations, you won 6 - 0!
Bad idea, by moving on the source you would have won a point.
You do not have pieces of this type anymore.
You must put your piece on an empty square or on a smaller piece.
You must pick your piece among the remaining ones.
You must pick one of your remaining pieces or one piece on the board that is the biggest of its square.
You are performing a move, you must select a landing square.
The goal of Encapsule is to align three of your pieces. Here, Dark wins.
Putting a piece

This is the initial board.

You're playing Dark. Pick one of your piece on the side of the board and put it on the board.

Another possible action is to move one of your pieces that is already on the board.

You're playing Dark, click on your piece already on the board and then on any empty square of the board.
Particularity

At Encapsule, pieces encapsulate each other. It is therefore possible to have up to three pieces per square! However, only the biggest piece of each square counts: you cannot win with a piece that is "hidden" by a bigger piece. Similarly, you cannot move a piece if it is encapsulated by a bigger piece. Finally, you cannot encapsulate a piece with a smaller piece. Here, Dark can win now in various ways.

You're playing Dark, try to win by making a move, and not by putting a new piece on the board.
You won, but the exercise is to win while moving a piece!
Attack
The move distance of your phalanx puts it out of the board.
There is something in the way of your phalanx.
Your phalanx must be bigger than the one you are capturing.
You took a phalanx of size and moved it steps. Phalanx cannot move further than their sizes.
This square is not aligned with the direction of the phalanx.
A phalanx can't contain pieces outside of the board.
A phalanx cannot contain an empty square.
A phalanx cannot contain a piece of the opponent.
Piece > Row Domination > Alignment > Row Presence
Positional
Number of empty rows
Number of soldier rows
Initial board
This is the initial board of Epaminondas. The top line is the starting line of Light. The bottom line is the starting line of Dark.

After multiple moves, if at the beginning of its turn, a player has more pieces on the opponent's starting line than the number of pieces the opponent has on the player's starting line, the player wins. Here, it's Dark's turn to play: Dark has therefore won.
Here, it is Light's turn. Light wins because they have two pieces on Dark's starting line, and Dark only has one on Light's starting line.

Here is the starting board. Dark plays first. Let's start with moving a single piece:
  1. Click on a piece.
  2. Click on a empty neighboring square.

You're playing Dark, move a piece.
Congratulations, you are in advance. But this is not the exercise here, try again.
This is how you move a single piece.
Moving a phalanx

A line of several pieces is called a phalanx. Let us now see how to move a phalanx along a line:
  1. Click on the first piece of the phalanx.
  2. Click on one of the squares highlighted in yellow; you can move your phalanx up to a distance equal to its length.

You're playing Dark, move a phalanx!
Failed! You moved only one piece.

Congratulations! The moved pieces can be horizontally, vertically, or diagonally aligned. The move should be made along this axis, forward or backwards. There can be no opponent nor holes in the phalanx.

In order to capture an opponent phalanx, it must be aligned with the phalanx you are moving and be strictly shorter. The first piece of your phalanx should land on the first piece of the opponent's phalanx that you want to capture.
You're playing Dark, capture a phalanx.

Congratulations, you made it! Note that the diagonal phalanx was not aligned with your phalanx, hence even if it is longer, this does not prevent you from capturing some of its pieces on another alignment.
Failed, you have not captured the phalanx.
You can only capture when 4 or more of your pieces are aligned, and it is not the case.
You must select a valid capture that contains 4 pieces or more.
There are still possible captures to be done.
Pieces must be inserted in spaces on the edge of the board.
You must select a valid placement direction.
You must select a placement with a direction alongside the insertion space.
You cannot place a piece on a complete line.
This piece belongs to two captures. Please select another piece in the capture you'd like to make.
You cannot insert a piece here, as all lines are full. Select another space.

The goal of Gipf is to capture the opponent's piece so that the opponent can no longer play. This is the initial board. Each player has 12 pieces on the side and 3 pieces on the board. When, at its turn, a player has no more pieces on the side, that player cannot play anymore and loses the game. The first player plays with the dark pieces, the second player plays with the light pieces.

Pieces can only enter the board through the edges. To insert a new piece:
  1. Click on a space on the edge of the board.
  2. If that space was already occupied, click on the arrow that indicates the direction in which you want to push the piece(s) already on the corresponding line.
You cannot push when a line is full.

You're playing Dark, insert a piece.

To capture, you must align 4 of your own pieces, which will be the first 4 captured pieces. There are multiple important aspects of a capture:
  1. When 4 pieces are captured, all pieces that are directly aligned with these 4 pieces are also captured.
  2. As soon as there is an empty space on the line, the capture stops.
  3. Your own pieces that are captured go back to your stock. Your opponent's pieces however are really captured and do not go back to your opponent's stock.
  4. If you create a line of 4 of your opponent's pieces, it will be at the beginning of your opponent's turn that your opponent can capture them. This means that a turn happens in three phases:
    1. Pick the capture(s) resulting from the last move of your opponent (by clicking on it).
    2. Make your insertion.
    3. Pick the capture(s) resulting from your move (by clicking on it).

You're playing Dark, you can make a capture, do it.
Congratulations, you have gotten 4 of your pieces back. This is not the most useful capture. Let's now see how captures can really be useful.

Here, there are three different ways for Dark to capture.
  1. One way does not capture any of your opponent's pieces.
  2. Another way captures one of your opponent's pieces.
  3. The last way captures two of your opponent's pieces.

You're playing Dark, capture the most pieces from your opponent.
Congratulations, you have gotten back 4 of your pieces and captured 2 of the opponent's. The most you can get is 3 per capture.
Failed, the best capture was taking 2 of your opponent's pieces

Here, you must capture at the beginning of your turn. This is due to a move of your opponent at the previous turn (even though this is a fictitious board for pedagogical purpose). After your capture, by performing the right move you can even capture two more of your opponent's pieces! Keep it mind that the most useful in a capture is to take your opponent's pieces.

You're playing Dark, capture the most pieces from your opponent.
Failed, the best capture takes 2 of your opponent's pieces.
Congratulations, you have gotten 12 of your pieces back and captured 2 of your opponent's pieces.
Minimax
This move is a ko, you must play somewhere else before you can play in this intersection again.
We are in the counting phase, you must mark stones as dead or alive or accept the current board by passing your turn.
You cannot accept before the counting phase.

You cannot commit suicide.
Handicap
Preliminary information

The game of Go is played on a board called a Goban, and the stones are placed on the intersections. The traditional board is made of 19x19 intersections, but on this website we have the 13x13 board. (For shorter parts, 9x9 and 5x5 boards exist, but are not yet available here). For this tutorial, we will use a smaller board for pedagogical purposes.

The object of the game is to have the most points at the end of the game. We call "territories" the intersections that are empty and isolated from the rest of the Goban by the stones of a single player. Here, Dark has 9 territories on the left, and Light has 8 on the right. The top part belongs to no one. Each player's score at the end of the game is the sum of that player's territories and captures.
Simple capture

An isolated stone, like the one in the middle here, has 4 neighboring intersections (not 8, because we do not count diagonals). It is said of a group which has exactly 2 free neighboring squares, that this group has two liberties. If Dark plays on the last liberty of the light stone, this stone is removed from the Goban (captured) and Dark earns one point.

You're playing Dark. The light piece on the board only has one liberty left, play there.
Congratulations, you have earned one point.
Failed, try again by playing on one of the intersections directly next to the light stone.
Capturing multiple stones

Stones that are connected horizontally or vertically must be captured at the same time, and are not capturable in isolation.

You're playing Dark. The light group here only has one liberty left, capture it.
Congratulations, you have earned three points and formed a territory.
Failed, you have not captured the group. Play on the last liberty of that group.
Suicide

In Go, suicide is forbidden. If putting a piece on an intersection removes the last liberty of your group and does not capture any stone, playing on that intersection would be a suicide and is therefore forbidden. Here, the top left intersection is a suicide for Light. On the bottom right, it would be a suicide for Dark, and on the bottom left it is not a suicide for any player.
Life and death (death)

From the capture rule follows the life and death notion: dead stones are stones that are definitely capturable (without losing anything else). Alive stones are stones that can never be captured. From the capture rule, Dark can play inside Light's territory and make a capture. In this case, we say that Light has only one eye (its last liberty) and that Light is dead (even if not yet captured). At the end of the game, the dead stones will count as captures, and the intersections they occupy as territories.
Life and death (eyes)

Here, Light cannot play on the top left, nor on the bottom left. Light will never be able to capture Dark. We say that Dark has two eyes (the eye on the top left, and the one on the bottom left) and that Dark is alive.
Seki

If Dark plays on the middle line, Light will play on the opposite intersection and capture Dark. Similarly, if Light plays on the middle line, Dark will capture Light. In other words, there is no point in playing on the middle line. In that case, we say that stones in the middle are alive by Seki, and that both intersections in the middle are neutral.
Ko

A player, by putting a stone, cannot go back to an identical state of the Goban as before, in order to avoid an endless game.

You're playing Dark, capture the light stone.

Now, if Light tries to recapture the stone that Dark has just put on the Goban, this one would go back to its previous state, opening the door for an endless game. This intersection is therefore marked with a red square, to remind the players that this intersection is forbidden. This rule is called the Ko. The trick for Light is to try to create a big enough threat so that Dark must answer immediately, and does not have the time to protect its last stone, so that Light can capture it right after.

When a player feels that there is no advantage to putting a new stone, that player can pass a turn. The game phase stops when both players pass consecutively, and we move on to the counting phase. The dead groups are then marked by clicking on them. Every intersection in a player's territory earns that player a point. The winner is the one with most points.

You're playing Dark. A last stone is dead, mark it.

Congratulations, Dark has 15 territories and 3 light stones still present, called prisoners at the end of the game. The intersections where the prisoners are count as Dark's territory Light has 8 territories and 1 prisoner. The end result is therefore 18 - 9 for Dark.
Standard
Hexagonal

The game of Trigo is a triangular adaptation of the game of Go. Go is present on Everyboard, you can go learn it <a href="/tutorial/Go">here<a/>. This tutorial will only review the small differences that this experimental adaptation induced.
Freedom
Since the board is triangular, pieces have only one freedom in the corners.

Since the board is triangular, pieces have only two freedoms on the edges.
When pieces touch the board's edge with their corner only, like the pieces on the right, they're not really on the edges.
Since the board is triangular, pieces have three freedoms when they don't touch the edge.
Since the board is triangular, groups of two pieces have only one more freedom (making an atari a shisho by default).
Hexodia is played on a hexagonal board, your goal is to be the first to align 6 of your pieces.

At the first turn, the first player plays only one piece.

You're playing Dark, place your first piece by clicking on a space.
Hexagonal Diagonals

But an unusual kind of diagonal also exist in Hexodia. Here, Dark has made alignment in each of those three direction, in only one a victory is still possible.

You're playing Dark, do the winning move.
The queen bee can only move to one of its direct neighbors.
The beetle can only move to one of its direct neighbors.
The grasshopper must move in a straight line.
The grasshopper must jump over other pieces, without any empty spaces.
The spider must move on neighboring spaces.
The spider can only move around pieces that are in direct contact with it.
The spider cannot go twice through the same space in the same move.
The queen bee must be placed on the board before moving a piece.
Only the beetle is allowed to climb over other pieces.
You are not allowed to split the hive.
This piece must be able to slide to its destination.
You must place your queen bee at this turn!
You cannot drop a piece next to one of your opponent's stack.
You must always drop your piece on an empty space.
The piece you are dropping must be connected to the hive.
Hive is a game without a board, where pieces are placed on the side of each other, in a contiguous block called the hive. Each player has 11 pieces, representing various insects.

The object of the game at Hive is to surround the opponent's queen. Once the queen is surrounded by 6 pieces, no matter the owner of these pieces, the game ends. The player with a queen that is not surrounded wins. In case both queens are fully surrounded at the same turn, it is a draw. Here, Dark won.
Placing the first and second piece

There are two types of actions: drops and moves. Initially, the board is empty, so we will have to put (drop) pieces on the board. For the first piece dropped on the board, there is no placement restriction: you can choose any piece and put in on the board. The second piece, put by Light, will need to be put in a neighboring space of the first piece. To drop a piece on the board, select the piece of your choice in your remaining pieces (below the board), and then click on the space you want to drop it on.

You're playing Dark and starting the game, put any piece on the board.
Placing pieces after the second turn

After the second turn, you are still allowed to place pieces any time you want, as long as you respect two conditions:
  1. your piece must be connected to the hive, and
  2. the space on which you drop your piece must not touch a stack of the opponent.

You're playing Dark, drop a piece on the board.
Moving pieces: the queen bee

Once you have placed you queen bee on the board, you can move your pieces. You must place your queen bee on the board as your fourth piece at the latest. Each creature moves in a different way, and moves should respect two restrictions:
  1. the hive must always remain fully connected, and
  2. pieces should be able to physically slide to their destination (except for the beetle and grasshopper as we will see later).
The queen bee can move to any of its empty neighbors. To move a piece, click on it and then click on its destination. The possible destinations are highlighted.

You are playing Dark, move your queen bee.
Moving the beetle

The beetle moves like the queen bee, but it is allowed to climb on top of other pieces! Therefore, it need not adhere to the sliding restriction. Note that you are not allowed to drop the beetle on top of another piece in the drop phase, this can only be achieved when moving a beetle already on the board. A piece with a beetle on top is not allowed to move. A stack is considered to be of the player who has the beetle of the top.

You're playing Dark, block your opponent's queen by moving on top of it!
Inspecting stacks

When pieces are stacked together, you are allowed to inspect the stack to see which pieces are under the beetle. This works with opponent-controlled stacks too. To do so, you can simply click on any stack to see their composition.

You're playing Dark and your opponent has a beetle on top of one of your piece, click on it.
Moving the grasshopper

The grasshopper jumps over one or more pieces in a straight line, and stops at the first empty space encountered. It cannot jump over empty spaces, and can only move through jumps. Because it jumps, it does not adhere to the sliding restriction.

You're playing Dark. Jump over three pieces with your grasshopper!
Moving the soldier ant

The soldier ant is a powerful piece: it can move anywhere in the hive as long as it respects the sliding and the one hive restrictions!

You're playing Dark. Your queen bee is stuck, move your soldier ant to free up your queen!
You have not freed your queen, try again!
Moving the spider

Finally, the spider can move exactly 3 spaces at a time. It is not allowed to go twice through the same space in a move. As the spider crawls around other pieces, it can only move around pieces that are in direct contact with it. This means that the spider is not allowed to temporarily split the hive. For example, here, Dark's spider cannot go on the left as its first move. To do a spider move, select a spider and click on the three spaces that compose the move.

You're playing Dark, move your spider!
Restrictions

Let us clarify the two restrictions during moves.
  1. All pieces of the hive should always be connected in a way that there is a single hive. It can be the case that your piece disconnects from the hive when you slide it, but after the move there should be only one hive.
  2. Except grasshoppers and beetles, all moves should be done by sliding the piece without disturbing the rest of the hive.
Observe here how the queen bee is stuck, as it is not possible to slide it without moving one of the other pieces. Moreover, moving it would split the hive in two.
Passing your turn

Finally, it is possible that you are not able to do any move: when it is the case, you must pass your turn. Here, Dark must pass: the queen bee cannot move without disconnecting the hive, the beetle is stuck beneath another beetle, and a dropped piece would be in contact with an opponent's piece.
This piece is not of the color you have to play.
You can only move forward, orthogonally or diagonally.
This move is blocked by another piece.
You must play with the selected piece.

At Kamisado, there are two ways to win the game: either by moving one of your pieces on the opponent's starting line, or by forcing the opponent to make a move that blocks the entire game. Here, Dark wins because its brown piece is on Light's starting line, on the top left.
Initial board and initial move

Here is the initial board. At Kamisado, pieces can only move forward, vertically or diagonally. You're playing first, with dark pieces, you can make your first move.

You're playing Dark, click on the piece of your choice and click on a landing square.
Perfect! Note that each of your piece has a different color.

Let us now consider the move of Light, after the blue piece has been moved by Dark. All moves after the initial move must be made from the piece that corresponds to the color of the square upon which the last move ended. Here, the last move ended on the pink square, hence the pink piece must move. It is already selected, you do not have to click on it.

You're playing Light, move your piece on a blue square.
You have not moved your pink piece on a blue square!
Stuck situation

Dark moved to another pink square, hence you have to move your pink piece again. However, your pink piece is stuck! In this case, you must pass your turn. Dark will now have to play by moving its pink piece.
Victory by blocking

At any time, if a player blocks the entire game, that player loses. In other words, if a player forces its opponent to move a piece that the opponent cannot move, and the player cannot move its own piece of the same color, then that player loses. Here, you're playing Dark and you can force your opponent to create such a situation, hence you can force your opponent to lose!

You're playing Dark, analyze the board and make the winning move.

Perfect! Your opponent must move its green piece on the orange square, forcing you to play with your orange piece. Your orange piece will be stuck and you will have to pass your turn. Your opponent will have to pass its turn too because its orange piece is also stuck: the game is completely stuck. In this case, the last player to have moved a piece loses. Here, your opponent will have moved its green piece last, you therefore win!
Control
Control and Domination
You cannot go backward with normal pieces!
You cannot capture an empty square, nor jump over it!
You must capture when it is possible!
You must finish this capture!
This piece cannot move!
A capture should be a double diagonal step. Look at the green indicators to help you!
You must move in a single diagonal step!
You cannot jump over the same square several times!
Lasca: origins
Lasca is a game based on draughts created in 1911 by Emanuel Lasker, chess world champion. It's played on a 7x7 board, each player has 11 pieces.
The goal of Lasca is, like for draughts, to render the opponent unable to move, either by capturing all his pieces, either by blocking them.
Steps

A simple step is made by one diagonal move forward, left or right. Click on the chosen piece, then on its landing square.

You are playing Dark, do the first move.

A capture happens when you jump diagonally over an opponent piece to land right behind it. You have to capture when you can. It is the case here, so click on the piece that must capture, and then on its landing square.

You're playing Dark, go ahead.
Congratulations, notice that the captured piece was not removed from the board, but put below the capturing pieces.
Multiple captures

If, after the beginning of your capture, the piece that you just moved can capture another piece, it has to capture until it can no longer capture. To do so, you must then click again on the next landing square. Note that, you cannot jump twice over the same stack.

You are playing Dark, a double capture is possible, go ahead.
Minority capture is allowed
If you have several capture choices, you are allowed to choose any of them. For example if one choice is to capture one piece, and the other choice is to capture two pieces, you can choose either.
Promotion

When a stack reaches the last line, its commander becomes an officer, and gains the ability to go backward, which is illegal for the other pieces! One of your piece could be promoted now.

You're playing Dark. Do it.
You did not choose the correct stack, and got no promotion.
Officer move

Officers can move and capture backward as well as forward.

You're playing Dark, move your officier!
You did not move your officer.
Your move should have a length equal to the number of pieces that exist on the same line.
You cannot jump over the opponent's pieces.
This piece has no possible move, select another one.

At Lines of Actions, the goal is to group your pieces contiguously, orthogonally and/or diagonally. Here, Dark wins the game: Dark's pieces are forming a single group, while Light's pieces form three groups.

Here is the initial board. Moves can be made orthogonally or diagonally. The length of a move is equal to the number of pieces that are on the line of the move. Note that there is a helping indicator to let you know where a piece can land when you select it.

You're playing Dark, make the first move!
Jumping

During a move, it is possible to jump above your own pieces. But it is forbidden to jump over the opponent's pieces.

You're playing Dark, make a jump over one of your pieces on the following board.
Failed. You did not jump over one of your pieces.

Here is a different board. Pick the dark piece in the middle (line 4, column 4) and observe its possible moves.
  • Horizontally, this piece can move only of one square because it is the only piece on this line.
  • Vertically, this piece can move of three squares because there are in total three pieces on that vertical line. But it can only go up, as below it the landing square is occupied by one of your pieces.
  • Diagonally, only one move is possible: on the diagonal that contains three pieces, only in the direction where it does not jump over one of the opponent's pieces. On the other diagonal, there are too many pieces to end the move on the board.

You're playing Dark, make one of these moves.
Failed. This was not one of the expected moves.

If a move ends on an opponent's piece, it is captured and removed from the board. However, a move cannot end on one of the player's pieces. Watch out, having less pieces at Lines of Action makes a victory easier, as there are less pieces to regroup! If a player has only one piece, that player wins the game.

On the following board, try to capture one piece with Dark.
Tie

In the special case where a move ends up connecting all pieces of both player, simultaneously, then the game ends up with a tie.

You're playing Dark, force the tie in one move.
You must flip your lodestone before putting it back on the board.
As long as there are pressure plates, you must place all the pieces that you have captured on them.
You must place your lodestone on a non-crumbled square!
You placed too many captures on the same pressure plate, which has not enough space left.
You must place your captures on the pressure plates, on the side of the board.
You cannot place any capture now, you must first place your lodestone on the board!

Lodestone is played on a 8x8 board, which contains so-called pressure plates along the board, that will contain captured pieces. The initial board is shown here. The object of the game is to be the only player with pieces remaining on the board. To do so, you will have to either push your opponent's pieces off the board, or to crush them with your pieces. You will do it by using a lodestone.
Selecting a lodestone

To perform a move, you have to place your lodestone on the board. Your lodestone has two sides:
  • its repelling side with which it will repel the opponent's pieces (indicated by the outward triangles of your opponent's color on the lodestone), and
  • its attracting side with which it will attract your pieces (indicated by the inward triangles of your color on the lodestone).
Your lodestone can be placed to move pieces orthogonally or diagonally. All available lodestone sides and orientation are shown below the board.

You're playing Dark. Select the lodestone that repels your opponent's pieces diagonally.
This is not the right lodestone, try again.
The repelling lodestone

Upon placing a lodestone on the board, it will move all pieces it acts upon (according to its direction and orientation) simultaneously. Let us first see how the repelling lodestone acts on the pieces. All the opponent's pieces aligned with the lodestone, as indicated by the triangles' orientations, will be pushed one square away from the lodestone. An opponent's piece will be blocked in case it encounters on its way either one of your piece, a lodestone, or another blocked piece. Finally, if an opponent's piece falls out of the board, it is captured.
The attracting lodestone

When the lodestone is on its attracting side it will pull your pieces one square towards it. In case one of your pieces encounters a lodestone on its way or another blocked piece, it is blocked. However, if it encounter an opponent's piece, it will capture it.
Flipping the lodestone

Note that, after every move, you must flip your lodestone: if it was on its repelling side, you must use it on its attracting side, and vice versa. Also, you are allowed to place your lodestone on the same location as it was on your previous turn.

To summarize, it is possible to capture the opponent's pieces in two ways:
  • with a repelling lodestone, by pushing your opponent's pieces out of the board, or
  • with an attracting lodestone, by moving your pieces on your opponent's pieces.
Once a lodestone is placed and the pieces have been moved and/or captured, in case any of the opponent's pieces have been captured, you have to place them on the pressure plates that lie around the board. To do so, click on an empty space of the pressure plate of your choice for each capture. You can cancel this by clicking again on a piece you just put on a pressure plate.

You're playing Dark. Try to perform a move that captures at least one of your opponent's piece, and place your capture(s) on pressure plates.
Crumbling a first pressure plate

When a pressure plate is full, it will crumble and take a full row or column of the board with it! All pieces that are on the crumbled squares are considered lost, but will not have to be placed on pressure plates. You have here a board with a pressure plate that only requires one more piece to crumble.

You're playing Dark. Perform a move that captures at least one piece, and fill that pressure plate to make it crumble.
You must capture and place your capture on the top pressure plate to make it crumble!
Crumbling a second pressure plate

Once a pressure plate has crumbled, a shorter pressure plate takes it place. It is the case here, where only 3 spots are available on the top pressure plate.

You're playing Dark. Perform a move that captures enough pieces to fill the top pressure plate, and make it crumble.
You must capture and place your capture on the top pressure plate to make it crumble a second time!
Minimal board
After a pressure plate has crumbled for a second time, there is no more pressure plate available on that side. In case all pressure plates have crumbled, the board is reduced to a 4x4 board.
Making the lodestone fall

If, at any point during the game, your lodestone is situated on a square that crumbles with a pressure plate, you will be allowed to select any lodestone side on your next turn.

In this board, playing Dark, you can place your lodestone and make a pressure plate crumble so that your lodestone falls too, allowing to choose more freely its side on your next turn. Do it!
Congratulations! At your next turn, you will be allowed to place your lodestone on any side.

In order to win, you must take out all of your opponent's pieces.

Here, you can win in a single move, do it!
This is not the winning move. Try again.
Bonus fact: Awalé is the most common of all Mancalas.
Big sowing

When there are enough seeds to make a full turn, something else happens.

You're playing Dark. Sow the house that contains 12 seeds.
See, the house that you sowed has not been refilled, and the sowing immediately continued to the next house (which therefore contains two seeds).

After sowing, if the last seed falls in an opponent's house and if there are now two or three seeds in this house, the player captures these two or three seeds.

You're playing Dark, do a capture!
Well done! This was a simple capture, now let us see how to make multiple captures.

By sowing from your leftmost house, you will end in the opponent's second leftmost house, which now contains 2 seeds, so this will be a capture. But now, the house right before it contains 3 seeds, which is also capturable, so, that house will get captured as well!

You're playing Dark, do a capture!
Nice, you win 3 points from the first house, and 2 from the second!
Interrupted capture

By clicking on your leftmost house, you end up on the 3rd house, which is capturable.

You're playing Dark, do a capture!
Notice that because the second house was not capturable, the capture was interrupted and you have not captured the first house.
Capture on the other side only
You're playing Dark. Try to capture the two leftmost houses of the opponent.
Congratulations! Notice that the capture was interrupted when entering your territory: you cannot capture your own houses!
You have only captured one house, try again!
Do not starve

You have a very nice capture that seems possible: it seems that you can capture all the opponent's seeds!

You're playing Dark. Try it.
Sadly, you cannot capture here, otherwise the opponent could not play after you. When this happens, the move can be made, but no capture takes place!
Feeding is mandatory

You cannot let another player starve, meaning that if your opponent has no seeds anymore and if you can give them at least one, you have to do it.

You're playing Dark. Give a seed to your opponent!
Congratulations! Note that you can choose to give your opponent the least number of seeds if it is better for you. It is often a good way to have easy captures!

A game is won as soon as one player has captured 25 seeds, as that player has more than half of all the seeds.

You're playing Dark, sow the leftmost house.
Also, as soon as on player cannot play, the other player captures all the seeds in its own side. Here, it was the first player's turn, and the second player has taken all the remaining seeds.

Multiple laps sowing

However, the distribution only stops when the last seed is dropped in a house that contains zero or three seeds (before drop).

So, after landing in the house with 2 seeds (then 3), a second lap has been started.
Captures during distribution

If, during some distribution, you pass by one of your houses that contains 3 seeds, and drop a fourth seed, you capture the house immediately, then continue the distribution!

You're playing Dark, do such a move!

If, during some distribution, you pass by one house of the opponent that contains 3 seeds, and drop a fourth seed, the opponent captures the house immediately, while you continue to distribute.

Though, if your very last seed is dropped in a house of the opponent that contains 3 seeds (4 with your seed), you capture it immediately!

Seeds by house

is a Mancala. Mancala is the name of a family of board games that dates back at least to the third century. Mancalas are games of distribution (sowing) and capture. Their goal is to capture the most seeds. The spaces in Mancalas are called the houses. The ones on the extreme left and right are called the stores, they contain the seeds that each player captured. As you are playing Dark, the 6 houses on the bottom are yours.
Sowing

The main move in Mancala games is sowing, let's see how seeds are sown. As you are playing Dark, the 6 houses on the bottom are yours.

When you sow a house, the seeds it contains are sown clockwise, one seed per house.

Click on the rightmost house!
Look at the 4 houses that follow clockwise the one you picked, they now contain one more seed. This is how seeds are sown: one by one from the house next to the one they come from, clockwise.
Failed. Choose the rightmost house on the bottom.
Failed. You did not capture anything. Try again.
Bonus fact: Kalah has been created in the U.S.A in 1940 by William Julius Champion Jr.
The Kalah

The houses on the extreme left and right, unaligned with the others, are the Kalah. Yours is on the left, the opponent's on the right. When sowing, before passing from your leftmost house to the leftmost house of the opponent, you must drop one seed in your Kalah, but you won't have to drop seed in your opponent's Kalah. When you make a capture, the captured seeds are put in your Kalah.

You're playing Dark. Make a move that passes through your Kalah then feeds opponent's houses.
As you see, three houses have been fed in addition to your Kalah.
Failed. Choose the three leftmost house on the bottom.

When ending in the Kalah, you must distribute again.

You're playing Dark, play the house that ends up in the Kalah then do a second distribution!
This move only distributed one house, do one distribution that ends in the Kalah, then do a second one!

When the last seed of a distribution ends up in one of your empty houses, if the opposite house is filled, then you capture both houses. On this board, such a move is possible.

You're playing Dark, do a capture!
You did not capture, try again!

At any moment, when one player has more than 24 seeds in their Kalah, they win. That can happen before the board is empty, but, there is also a second way. When you don't have any seed in your houses, the game is over and your opponent takes all the remaining seeds from their houses. Here, your opponent just need one more point to win and will get it next turn if you allow it.

You're playing Dark, win!
Since there is no longer seeds in the opponent houses, all your seeds have been captured by you. Congratulations, you won!

At Martian Chess, the goal is to have the most points at the end of the game. Each piece is assigned a value, you win this value when capturing the piece. The board is divided in two by a line called the canal. There is one side for each player. You do not own pieces, but you control the ones on your side of the canal. Pieces are colored to help you: they will change color when crossing the canal.
The pieces

The pieces are dark on the side of the first player, the light ones on the side of the second one. There are 3 kind of pieces:
  • The Queens: represented as circles with 3 dots.
  • The Drones: represented as circles with 2 dots.
  • The Pawns: represented as circles with one dot.
Moving pawns

Pawns are worth one point. They can move one step diagonally.

You're playing Dark, move a pawn.
This is not a pawn!
Moving drones

Drones are worth two points. They can move one or two steps in any direction, in a straight line, without jumping over other pieces.

You're playing Dark, move a drone.
This is not a drone!
Moving queens

Queens are worth three points. They can move any number of steps in any direction, in a straight line, without jumping over other pieces.

You're playing Light, move a queen.
This is not a queen!

When a piece crosses the canal and lands on another piece, you capture it and gain the value of that captured piece. However, you lose control of your piece as it crosses the canal!

A capture is possible for Light, do it.
Congratulations! By capturing that pawn, you won one point.
Field Promotion

It is sometimes possible to perform what is called a field promotion. If you are out of one type of piece, you can merge two pieces to add their value and get a new piece. For example, if you have no drones, you can merge two pawns into a drone. To merge two pawns, move one of your pawns on another.

Such a move is possible for Light. Do it.
This is not a field promotion!

The other kind of field promotion is to merge a drone and a pawn to obtain a queen.

Such a move is possible for Light. Do it.
Call the clock

When the game seems to be going nowhere, you can "call the clock" during your turn. To do so, click on the clock symbol on the right, then perform your move. Once the clock is called, seven more turn will be played.

You're playing Dark. Call the clock and perform a move.
You did not call the clock!
Restarting the clock

If the clock has been called, whenever a capture is done the countdown restarts.

You're playing Dark, do a capture to restart the countdown.
This is not a capture, the game is now over, please retry!
End game (by clock)

When seven turns have passed after the clock has been called, the player with the most points win. If both player have the same number of points, it is a tie.

You're playing Light, do the last move.
End by emptyness

When a player's last piece is moved into the opponent territory, the game ends. If both players have the same number of points, the last player win!

Light player can win this way, do it!
Your piece is still in you territory!
Please put your piece in an incomplete column.

The board at Four in a Row is made of 7 columns and 6 rows, and it is initially empty. The first player plays Dark, the second plays Light. The goal is to be the first to align 4 of its pieces (horizontally, vertically, or diagonally).
Dropping a piece
Click on any space in any column.
As you can see, the piece falls at the bottom of the column.
You're playing Dark. Place your piece so that you create a horizontal alignment of 4 of your pieces.
You won!
Failed, you have not aligned 4 pieces and missed an opportunity to win.
Other victory
You can also align 4 pieces diagonally or vertically.
If the quadrant to turn is neutral, please just use move without rotation.
No quadrant is neutral, you must pick a quadrant to rotate.
The initial Pentago board is made of 6x6 spaces, subdivided in 4 quadrants, which can each rotate.
The goal at Pentago is to align 5 of your pieces. In the following board, Dark wins.

At their turn, players put a piece on the board and possibly rotate one quadrant. As long as there are neutral quadrants, i.e., quadrants that would not change after being rotated, a player may skip rotating a quadrant. To do this, you have to click on the crossed circle that appears at the center of the board when it is possible.

You're playing Dark, do a simple move.
You have made a move with a rotation. This tutorial step is about moves without rotations!
Move with rotation

After putting a piece, arrows will appear on non-neutral quadrants.

You're playing Dark, place a piece on a quadrant and do a rotation!
You made a move without rotation, try again!
Congratulations! Note that if all quadrants are neutral after you have put your piece, there will be no rotation.
Captured stones needed to win
Size of captures

Pente is played on a 19x19 board, on which the pieces are put on the intersections of the squares. The object of the game is to align 5 of your pieces, or to capture 10 pieces of your opponent. Initially, a piece of the second player is in the center location of the board.

At your turn, you must drop one piece on any empty space of the board. There is no other restriction.

You're playing Dark, put a piece on the board.

You can capture exactly two pieces of your opponent by sandwiching them between two of your pieces.

You're playing Light and you can capture, do it!
Placing in a sandwich position

You can safely place a piece next to another of your piece in what would look like a sandwich from the opponent's pieces. This is a safe move.

You're playing Light and have the opportunity to do such a move here, do it!

Remember, to win you can either align 5 or your pieces, or capture 10 pieces of your opponent. Here, as Light, you have already captured 8 pieces and you only need two more to win.

You're playing Light, you can win in two ways. Win!
You must move your pieces upward.
Your piece must land on the board or on 4 other pieces.
You cannot move a supporting piece.
You cannot capture.
Your first capture is invalid.
Your second capture is invalid.
You must capture one or two pieces, not more.

At Pylos, the goal is to be the last to play. To do this, you have to save up your pieces. As soon as a player puts its last piece, that player loses the game immediately. Here is what the initial board looks like, it is a board of 4 x 4 squares. This board will become a pyramid, little by little. It will be filled by the pieces of your stock. Each player has 15 pieces.

When it is your turn, you can always drop one of your piece on an empty square. The gray squares are where you can drop your pieces.

Click on one of the squares to drop a piece there.
There you go, as simple as that.
Climbing

When 4 pieces form a square, it is possible to put a fifth piece on top. However, when that happens, you can save a piece by climbing instead of dropping a piece. To climb:
  1. Click on one of your free pieces, which should be lower than the landing square.
  2. Click on an empty landing square, higher than your selected piece.

You're playing Dark, go ahead and climb!

Congratulations!
Some important notes:
  1. You cannot move a piece that is directly below another one.
  2. Of course, you cannot move the opponent's pieces.
  3. You can only climb when the landing square is higher than the starting square.
Square

When the piece you just moved or dropped is the fourth one of a square of your color, you can choose anywhere on the board one or two of your pieces. These pieces will be removed from the board, allowing you to save up one or two pieces. A chosen piece must not be directly below another piece. A chosen piece can be the piece you just placed.

You're playing Dark. Form a square, click on one of the four pieces, then click on the V symbol on the bottom right to finalize your move.
Congratulations, you have saved up one piece. Note, you can cancel your selection by clicking again on the piece.

You're playing Dark.

Do like in the previous step, but this time click on two different pieces before validating.
Failed, you only captured one piece.
Congratulations, you have saved up two pieces.
You must give a piece.
That piece is already on the board.
You cannot give the piece that was in your hands.
Player One Level
Player Two Level

Quarto is an alignment game. The goal is to align four pieces that have at least one common aspect:
  • their color (light or dark),
  • their size (big or small),
  • their pattern (empty or dotted),
  • their shape (round or square).
Here, we have a board with a victory by an alignment of dark pieces. Note that the pieces are not owned by any player.
Placement

Every placement occurs in two steps: placing the piece you have in hand (in the small square) on a square of the board, and picking a piece that the opponent will have to place, by clicking on one of the pieces inside the dotted square. If you prefer, the order of these two steps can be reversed. Keep in mind that the second click confirms the move.

Make a move.
Perfect!
Situation

We have here a tricky situation.

Analyze the board and play your move, carefully paying attention not to let the opponent win on the next move.
Well done!

Failed! Your opponent can either align:
  • the squares horizontally on the third line or vertically on the third column,
  • small pieces horizontally on the first line or vertically on the second or third column,
  • empty pieces horizontally on the first line or vertically on the first column,
  • clear pieces diagonally.

A game of Quarto can be configured to make it more complicated for one or both players.
When you create a game and you want to change the original configuration, you can add a level to one or both players. When your level increases, it becomes easier for you to win. So, if the first player is weaker at this game, make the first player play at level two and the game will be more even and interesting.
At level two, a player can win by grouping pieces with a common criterion on a 2x2 square.
In this board, Light can win by making a square.

You're playing Light, win.
Wrong, you could have won by making a square.
You must pick a space from the edge of the board.

At Quixo, the goal is to align 5 of your pieces. The first player plays with dark pieces, the second with light pieces. The board is made of 25 spaces spread over a 5x5 square. Every piece has a neutral side, a light side, and a dark side.
What a move looks like (without animation)

When it is your turn:
  1. Click on one of your pieces or on a neutral one. You cannot choose a piece of the opponent. You can only choose a piece from the edge of the board.
  2. Pick a direction in which you want to send the piece (by clicking on the arrow).
You have to imagine that the piece you picked has been moved to the other side of the board, in the chosen direction. Once on the other side, all pieces will move by one space in the opposing direction. Afterwards, if the piece was neutral, it will become yours and takes your color.

For example, take the bottom right neutral piece, and move it to the left (you're playing Light).
See how the four dark pieces have been moved one space to the right. The neutral piece has been move 4 pieces to the left and has become light.

You already know everything you need in order to play, but there is one last particularity. If you create a line of 5 of your pieces, you win. If you create a line of 5 of your opponent's pieces, you lose. If you create both, you lose too!

You can win with this board, try it. You're playing Light.
Your move should switch at least one piece.

At Reversi, the pieces are double sided: one dark side for the first player, one light side for the second player. When one piece is flipped, its owner changes. The player owning the most pieces at the end of the game wins. Here, Dark has 28 points and Light has 36, hence Light wins.

At the beginning of the game, pieces are placed as shown here. For a move to be legal, it must sandwich at least one piece of the opponent between the piece you're putting and another of your pieces.

Do any move by clicking to put your piece Dark plays first.

A move can also capture a bigger line, and more than one line at a time

You're playing Light here. Play on the bottom left to see a capture.
Lower and more to the left, please.
Passing a turn

If, during its turn, a player has no move that would allow that player to flip a piece, that player must pass Moreover, if the next player could not play neither, the game ends before the board is full, and points are counted in the usual way.
You can only rebound on dark spaces.
You can only rebound on empty spaces.
You must pick one of your pyramids first.
You must pick one of your pyramids.
Those two spaces are not neighbors.
Those two spaces have no intermediary neighbor.
You can move one or two spaces, not .
Sâhârâ is played on a board where each space is a triangle. Each player has six pyramids.

At Sâhârâ, the object of the game is to immobilize one of the opponent's pyramids. To do so, you have to occupy all neighboring space of that pyramid. Here, Light has lost because its leftmost pyramid is immobilized.
Simple step

To immobilize your opponent, you have to move your pyramids. When a pyramid shares its vertices with light spaces, it can move on these spaces (we call this a simple step). To perform a move:
  1. Click on one of your pyramids.
  2. Click on one of its two or three neighboring spaces in order to move your pyramid there.

You're playing Dark, do any simple step.
You have made a double step, which is good but it is the next exercise!
Double step

When a pyramid shares its vertices with dark spaces, it can move one or two steps. To do so:
  1. Click on the pyramid to move.
  2. Click on one of the 6 destinations that you can reach in two steps: the 6 neighboring light spaces of the 3 dark spaces that are neighbors of your pyramid.

You're playing Dark, do a double step.
Failed! You have made a single step.
You cannot insert a piece, all your pieces are already on the board.

Your push is invalid: it is either not straight, is not pushing anything, or is leaving the board.

You should select the orientation of your piece by clicking on one of the arrows.

The goal at Siam is to be the first to push a mountain out of the board. The initial board contains three mountains, and no pieces are initially on the board. During its turn, a player can do one of the following actions:
  1. Put a new piece on the board.
  2. Change the orientation of one of its piece
  3. Move one of its piece and optionally reorient it.
  4. Take one of its pieces out of the board.
Inserting a piece

Each player has 5 pieces in total. As long as you have remaining pieces next to the board, you can insert new pieces. To do so:
  1. Click on one of your pieces from your reserve, next to board.
  2. Click on one of the highlighted squares to select a landing for your piece.
  3. Select an orientation for your piece by clicking on one of the arrows that appear on top of the board.

You're playing Dark, insert a piece on the board.

We will distinguish here "moving" and "pushing". A move is made from a piece's square to an empty neighboring square, horizontally or vertically. You can also move a piece out of the board. To move a piece:
  1. Click on it.
  2. Click on the square on which you want the piece to move. You can also click a second time on your piece to change its orientation without moving it.
  3. Select the orientation of your piece by clicking one one of the arrows that appear on top of the board.

You're playing Dark. Try to move your piece that is already on the board one square upwards and to orient it to the left.
Congratulations, you made a side-slip!
Moving a piece out of the board

To move a piece out of the board, you do not have to pick an orientation after the move.

You're playing Dark, get that piece out of the board!
Congratulations, even if in this context it was not a useful move.
Failed, the piece is still on the board.

When the landing square of your move is occupied, we use the term "push". In order to push player pieces, the following conditions must hold:
  1. Your piece must already be oriented in the direction of the push.
  2. Along the line that you are pushing, the number of pieces (yours or your opponent's) that are oriented in the same way as the push should be strictly greater than the number of pieces oriented in the opposite way.
Look closely at the board. On the first row, you cannot push as there is exactly one piece in the opposite direction. On the second row, you can push because there are two pieces against one.

You're playing Dark. Vertically, you can push using your piece in the center, as there is no resistance on that axis. Do it.

To be able to push a mountain, you need at least one pusher per mountain. Each resistant (pieces in the opposite way) cancel the force of one pusher. In short, if there is no mountain, you need strictly more pushers than resistants. If there is a mountain, you need at least as much pushers than there are resistants and mountains. On the following board, as Dark, you can push the mountain on the first row. On the second and third row, because of the resisting forces, you cannot push. On the fourth row, you can push as there is one more pusher than resistant pieces.

You're playing Dark, push on the fourth row it.
Congratulations! Note that this move made you lose the game, you will see why in the next step.

The game ends when a mountain is pushed out of the board. If you pushed it and nobody is in front of you, you're the winner. However, if you were pushing an opponent oriented in the same direction as you, your opponent will win because that piece is closer to the mountain. However, if that opponent is closer to the mountain but not oriented towards it, victory will be yours.

Here, playing Dark, you can push a mountain off the board and either win, or lose. Choose correctly!
Failed, you lost.
You cannot move yet. Pick a space where you will put a new piece.
Several groups are of the same size, you must pick the one to keep.
You cannot choose which part to keep when one is smaller than the other.
You cannot put new pieces anymore. Pick a piece to move.
You must choose one of the biggest groups to keep it.
You cannot pick an empty space. Pick one of the biggest groups.
You must put this piece next to another piece.
This move does not disconnect your opponent's pieces. Try again with another piece.
You lost one of your pieces during this move. There is a way to disconnect an opponent's piece without losing any of yours, try again!

Six is a game without board, where pieces are placed on the side of each other, in a contiguous block. Each player has 21 pieces, with one for each player already on the board. The object of the game is to form one of the three winning shapes with your pieces.
Victory (line)

On this board, by putting your piece at the right place, you can align six of your pieces and win the game

Find the victory. You're playing Dark.
Victory (circle)

On this board, by putting your piece at the right place, you can form a circle with six of your pieces and win the game.

Find the victory. You're playing Dark.
Congratulations! Note that if a piece is inside the circle, it does not change anything.
Victory (triangle)

On this board, by putting your piece at the right place, you can form a triangle with six of your pieces and win the game.

Find the victory. You're playing Dark.
Second phase

After 40 turns, your pieces have all been placed and we move on to the second phase of the game. You now have to move your pieces, paying attention not to remove a piece that was preventing the opponent's victory. From now on, if after move, on or more pieces are disconnected from the largest group of pieces, these will be taken out of the game.

You're playing Dark. Make a move that disconnects one of your opponent's pieces.
Congratulations, your opponent now has one piece less and you're closer to victory!
Victory by disconnection

During the second phase of the game, on top of normal victories (line, circle, triangle), you can win by disconnection. If at any time, at least one player does not have enough pieces to win (less than 6), the game ends. The one with the most pieces wins. In case they both have the same number of pieces, it's a draw.

Here, you're playing Dark and you can win. Do it!
Special disconnection

During a disconnection, two or more groups could have the same size, in which case you will have to click on the group you wish to keep.

You're playing Dark, play such a move!
This move has not cut the board in two equal halves.
Failed. You did cut the board in two but you kept the half where you're in minority. Therefore, you lost! Try again.
You jumped too far! The maximum size of a jump is step!

Squarz is board control game. Here is the initial state. The goal is to have the most pieces at the end of the game.
Duplication

One of the two kinds of move you can do is the duplication. When you do one, you create a new piece. To do this, select one of your pieces, and click on one of its neighboring space.

You're playing Dark, make a duplication.
This was a jump, try to do a duplication.

The second type of move you can do is the jump. When you do one, your piece leaves its original space and jumps two spaces further. To do this, select one of your pieces, and click on its landing space two spaces further.

You're playing Light, make a jump.
This was a duplication, try a jump now.

When one of your pieces lands on a square, its adjacent opponent pieces become yours. This is called a capture.

You're playing Light, do a capture!

When one player can no longer play, the game ends, and the player with the most pieces wins. Here, you can do a final move and win.

You're playing Light, do it.

Bad choice, by making this move you allowed the opponent to win.

Try again!
